#Text=counterbalance of unctuous seasoning, which no doubt caused the
#Text= celebrated Leibnitz to say, in his treatise upon the chemistry of food,
#Text= now translated into English, and to which I have already referred in my
#Text= _Shilling Cookery Book_,   '  That among all the arts known to man, there is
#Text= none which enjoys a juster appreciation, and the products of which are
#Text= more universally admired, than that which is concerned in the
#Text= preparation of our food.
#Text=Led by an instinct which has almost reached the
#Text= dignity of conscious knowledge, as the unerring guide, and by the sense
#Text= of taste, which protects the health, the experienced cook, with respect
#Text= to the choice, admixture, and preparation of food, has made acquisitions
#Text= surpassing all that chemical and physiological science have done in
#Text= regard to the doctrine or theory of nutrition
#Text=.
#Text='  "
#Text=
#Text= "Well, no doubt if the celebrated Leibnitz, who is considered one of the
#Text= greatest authorities of the age, says so, you cannot be wrong, having
#Text= had so much practice in the culinary art."

column3:
_	_	_	

#Text=I also maintain that with the simplest and cheapest of all aliments,

column1: #Text= when in good condition, I have turned out a most wholesome and palatable
#Text= food, quite worthy of the most refined palate, or of that of the
#Text=initiated epicure.

column3:
_	_	_	

#Text=Upon my word, you are perfectly right; appetite is really the best of

#Text="I have not the pleasure of knowing that gentleman, yet, though I admire
#Text= his kitchen very much, and must admit that he keeps it in good order, I
#Text= shall certainly tell him when I see him that I do not agree with his
#Text= method of not seasoning the broths, &c., while in course of preparation.

#Text=Ah, I noticed that several of the men did exactly as you say this

column1: #Text= morning," said Miss Nightingale.
#Text="The parts which are well done were
#Text= placed loose upon the stick; and this explains the mystery--but I shall
#Text= alter that to-morrow."
#Text=Having afterwards inspected several extra-diet kitchens, and tasted
#Text= various things, I perceived what I could accomplish, both as regarded
#Text= convalescents and extra diets.
#Text=Miss Nightingale having again offered to
#Text= render any assistance in her power, left us; as she had a great deal to
#Text= attend to.
#Text=I retraced my steps to Dr.
#Text=Cumming  '  s, and stated my opinion
#Text= of the present system of cooking; and explained what I proposed doing,
#Text= of all of which he approved highly.
#Text=I then returned to the kitchen, and
#Text= sent a requisition for six rations of everything allowed for making the
#Text= soup.
#Text=I proceeded thus:--
#Text=
#Text= To eight pints of water I put four pounds of meat, a quarter of a pound
#Text= of barley, a little salt and pepper, and the allowance of vegetables,
#Text=and in about an hour I produced a very good soup--some of which I sent
#Text= to several doctors.
#Text=They tasted and praised it highly, as being very
#Text= nourishing and palatable.
#Text=I then carried some to Dr.
#Text=Cumming, who
#Text= approved of its composition; but expressed his opinion that it would
#Text= probably be too expensive.
#Text=I then informed him I had made it with the
#Text= ration allowance, taking the meat at half-diet scale.
#Text=He was much
#Text= pleased with the meat, which he pronounced highly palatable, and thought
#Text= that the seasoning should be put in with the other ingredients.
#Text=I
#Text= explained that I could still improve it by the simple addition of a
#Text= small quantity of sugar and flour.
#Text="The purveyor will not, I am certain, refuse that," said he.
#Text="Oh, I am aware of that; but I wish to manage it without increasing the
#Text= expense.

#Text=Milton came in, and though I had not had the pleasure of 
#Text= seeing that gentleman, from the description I had heard of him, and his
#Text=pleasing manner, I knew I was not mistaken in saying--Mr.

#Text=Milton, allow 
#Text= me to have the honour of tendering my best compliments and thanks for 
#Text= your prompt visit.

_	_	_	

#Text=No person could be more welcome here than you are, Monsieur Soyer.

_	_	_	

#Text=Not at all," I replied; "you will see a great change by to-morrow,

column1: #Text= which must be attributed chiefly to the politeness and cordial
#Text= assistance I have met with from the members of every
#Text= department--especially your own--which to me is the most important."
#Text="I have given orders that everything you may require is to be placed at
#Text= your disposal, if in store; and any alteration or suggestion which is
#Text= likely to be beneficial will be immediately attended to.

#Text=You are quite right, if they are all like those I saw this morning.

#Text=
#Text= She smiled, and requested the captain to have her removed to her cabin,
#Text= which was immediately done.
#Text=was the last political question
#Text= I put to him.
#Text=I am unwilling to append the bill of fare, as it might
#Text= give an unexpected appetite to my readers, and thus induce them to drop
#Text= this light reading for something more substantial.
#Text=That would not answer
#Text= my purpose, as I wish them to go on with the book without depreciating
#Text=they have also skewers of tripe and liver, heart, &c., tied on each side
#Text= of the haunch.
#Text=The Pacha ordered some to be cut off for me to taste,
#Text= which I did with great gusto, and really much approved of their sound
#Text= judgment in turning everything to advantage, and making additional
#Text= dishes of what we civilized people so cleverly throw away.
#Text=It was so
#Text= good, that I begged the Pacha to send a small dish up for Lord W.
#Text=Paulet
#Text= and a few others to taste, as it was best while very hot.
#Text=It had a
#Text= peculiar aromatic taste which imparts a delicate flavour, and was very
#Text= palatable.
#Text=The liver, which we of course use, was cut into small portions, and
#Text= mixed with the intestines.
#Text=The lambs were dressed in the same way, and
#Text= were still more delicate: they were so perfectly roasted, that every
#Text= part of the animals was the colour of a lump of gold.
#Text=ORIENTAL WAY OF ROASTING SHEEP AND LAMBS WHOLE,
#Text= A LA TURQUE.
#Text=Though a primitive method, it is far from being a bad one.
#Text=About a
#Text=board the _Baraguay d  '  Hilliers_ about ten, faint with fatigue and
#Text= hunger, having had no breakfast.
#Text=Such was camp-life at head-quarters.
#Text=It was like swimming between life
#Text= and death.
#Text=No one seemed to apprehend the least danger, while a
#Text= successful sortie on the part of the enemy would have placed every one  '  s
#Text= life in the greatest peril.
#Text=So much for the unprofitable business of
#Text= war!
#Text=Having fixed upon a spot for my kitchen, I immediately sent the stoves
#Text= to the camp.
#Text=As they happened to be close to the railway, they arrived
#Text= early the next morning.
#Text=In the course of the day I reached my field of
#Text= battle, and to my great surprise found--what?
#Text=Why, all my battery firing
#Text= for the support of the Highland Brigade.
#Text=The stoves had arrived early
#Text= enough for the men to use them in cooking their dinners.
#Text=Though I had
#Text= given special orders that no one should meddle with them until I
#Text= arrived, it gave me great pleasure to find that the men were using them
#Text= to the best advantage and without instruction.
#Text=In the first place, they
#Text= could not possibly burn more than twenty pounds of wood in cooking for a
#Text= hundred men, instead of several hundredweight, which was the daily
#Text=consumption.
#Text=Although I had not given them my receipts, they found they
#Text= could cook their rations with more ease, and hoped they should soon have
#Text= them for every-day use, instead of the small tin camp-kettles, and their
#Text= open-air system of cooking.
#Text=The process was very unsatisfactory, being
#Text= dependent upon good, bad, or indifferent weather, and the fuel was often
#Text= wet and difficult to ignite.
#Text=Colonel Seymour, whom I invited to see the
#Text= men using the stoves without tuition from me or anybody else, can
#Text= testify to the accuracy of this fact, having witnessed the process and
#Text= interrogated them upon the subject.
#Text=My reason, reader, for relating this circumstance, is because it
#Text= afforded me an assurance that I could render service to the army, and
#Text= that my exertions were of some use.
#Text=I saw even further than that; for I
#Text= inferred that if a soldier, who is not a cooking animal, being paid for
#Text= other purposes--and that talent a peculiar gift conferred in a greater
#Text= or less degree upon humanity--could without trouble or instruction cook
#Text= well in the open air and in all weathers, the stoves would certainly be
#Text= useful in all establishments, from a cottage to a college.
#Text=I do not say
#Text= anything of their use in hospitals, because they had been tried in those
#Text= establishments with full success, as far as military cooking was
#Text=concerned.
#Text=The idea of connecting baking, roasting, boiling and steaming
#Text= crossed my mind; and this, I felt with confidence, would render them
#Text= beneficial and useful to the public at large.
#Text=This idea I at once
#Text= communicated to the makers, and they have already acted upon my
#Text= suggestion.
#Text=I resolved upon my return to England to bring them out at as
#Text= cheap a rate as possible for the use of small or large families.
#Text=A
#Text= really useful and economical cooking stove is as much wanted in England
#Text= as sunshine on a November day--a stove by which all the usual domestic
#Text= cooking can be carried on, without having recourse to bricks and mortar,
#Text= and chimney-sweeps.
#Text=Smoky chimneys, as well as other minor nuisances too
#Text= numerous to mention, would be thus avoided.
#Text=Twelve pounds of coal, or
#Text= fifteen pounds of coke, will cook for one hundred men.
#Text="War," said I to myself, "is the evil genius of a time; but good food
#Text= for all is a daily and a paramount necessity."
#Text=These reflections led to
#Text= a further communication with Messrs.
#Text=Smith and Phillips, of Snow-hill.
#Text=I
#Text= took out a patent for the stoves.
#Text=This I did not like to do before I had
#Text= introduced them to the Government, as every one would have supposed that
#Text= I wished to make money by the patent.
#Text=The object of a patent, after such
#Text= a decided success, was to secure the solidity and perfection of the
#Text=cocoa round till melted, and forming a pulp not too thick, preventing
#Text= any lumps forming, add to it the remaining water, hot or cold; add the
#Text= ration sugar, and when just boiling, it is ready for serving.
#Text=If short
#Text= of cocoa in campaigning, put about sixty rations, and when in pulp, add
#Text= half a pound of flour or arrowroot.
#Text=EASY AND EXCELLENT WAY OF COOKING IN EARTHEN PANS.
#Text=A very favourite and plain dish amongst the convalescent and orderlies
#Text= at Scutari was the following:--
#Text=
#Text= Soyer  '  s Baking Stewing Pan, the drawing of which I extract from my
#Text= "Shilling Cookery."
#Text=The simplicity of the process, and the economical
#Text= system of cooking which may be produced in it, induced me to introduce
#Text= it here.
#Text=Each pan is capable of cooking for fifteen men, and no matter how hard
#Text= may be the meat, or small the cutting, or poor the quality,--while fresh
#Text= it would always make an excellent dish.
#Text=Proceed as follows:--Cut any
#Text=previously well washed or peeled, or any of these mixed to make up four
#Text= ounces, putting them in the pot with the meat.
#Text=I have used the green tops of leeks and the leaf of celery as well as
#Text= the stem, and found, that for stewing they are preferable to the white
#Text= part for flavour.
#Text=The meat being generally salted with rock salt, it
#Text= ought to be well scraped and washed, or even soaked in water a few hours
#Text= if convenient; but if the last cannot be done, and the meat is therefore
#Text= too salt, which would spoil the broth, parboil it for twenty minutes in
#Text= water, before using for soup, taking care to throw this water away.
#Text=_No. 17.
#Text=_--For fresh beef proceed, as far as the cooking goes, as for
#Text= salt beef, adding a teaspoonful of salt to the water.
#Text=_No. 18.
#Text=Pea Soup.
#Text=_--Put in your pot half a pound of salt pork, half a
#Text= pint of peas, three pints of water, one teaspoonful of sugar, half one
#Text= of pepper, four ounces of vegetables, cut in slices, if to be had; boil
#Text= gently two hours, or until the peas are tender, as some require boiling
#Text= longer than others--and serve.
#Text=not cease until the peas are reduced to a pulp.
#Text=Indian meal must also be
#Text= put into boiling water, and be well boiled for two hours.
#Text=Rice and
#Text= barley may be put into cold water, and be boiled until they can be
#Text= easily mashed between the fingers; the length of time depends upon
#Text= their quality.
#Text=--All kinds of food made of farinaceous ingredients, as
#Text= Indian meal, peas, rice, &c., increase in quantity when made the day
#Text= previous, and require more water when warmed up.
#Text=It will be perceived that I have omitted all kinds of spice except in
#Text= those dishes which are intended expressly for them, as I consider they
#Text= only flatter the appetite and irritate the stomach, and make it crave
#Text= for more food; my object being not to create an appetite but to satisfy
#Text= it; and when those dishes in which spice is introduced are given to the
#Text= poor, it should only be done by the advice of the medical man; but in
#Text= those cases where they have been accustomed to have them, they must be
#Text= reduced by degrees until their taste is brought round to that point most
#Text= conducive to health.
#Text=NO. 1.
#Text=--FOR TWO GALLONS.
#Text=to you how much the sick and wounded of this army, as well as those
#Text= who have their interest at heart, are indebted to you for the
#Text= improvement you have made in the cooking of these establishments.
#Text=Your alterations of the kitchens and stoves must add much to the
#Text= economy of fuel, which is of the greatest consequence here; and
#Text= your successful attempts, combined with simplicity of making such
#Text= palatable beverages and soups out of so small a portion of
#Text= ingredients, is highly advantageous.
#Text=Wishing you a pleasant voyage, and hoping to find the cooking in
#Text= camp as much improved as the cooking here,
#Text=
#Text= I am, yours ever faithfully,
#Text=
#Text= (Signed)      W.
#Text=PAULET, _Brigadier-General_.
#Text=I am sure General Simpson will afford you every assistance in
#Text= carrying out your wishes.
#Text=consider very desirable, so as to enable the men to have a change
#Text= in the way of cooking their dinner.
#Text=I have the honour to be, Sir,
#Text=
#Text= Your most obedient servant,
#Text= F.
#Text=C.
#Text=EVELEGH, Lieut.
#Text=-Col.,
#Text= _Commanding 20th Regiment_.
#Text=The Assistant-Adjutant-General,
#Text=
#Text= Fourth Division.
#Text=CAMP, SEBASTOPOL, _27th May, 1856_.
#Text=SIR,--Having had one of your field-stoves in use for some weeks,
#Text= for the men of the 23d Fusiliers, and all the companies having
#Text= taken their turn of cooking with it, I am happy to be able to bear
#Text= testimony to the great improvement you have effected in the
#Text=MONSIEUR SOYER,--The cooking-stove sent to my regiment on trial was
#Text= in use one week, and I am glad to be able to tell you was highly
#Text= approved of.
#Text=The soup was richer and superior in flavour, and the meat better
#Text= boiled.
#Text=It has the great advantage of cleanliness, also being capable of
#Text= service in the open air, needing only a shed to keep the weather
#Text= off those employed.
#Text=Yours very obediently,
#Text=
#Text= W.
#Text=H.
#Text=WELLESLEY, Colonel,
#Text= _Commanding Royal Fusiliers_.
#Text=Monsieur A.
#Text=Soyer.
#Text=CRIMEA, _31st May, 1856_.
#Text=I hereby certify that Soyer  '  s field-kitchen for fifty men has
#Text= recently been tried in the battalion under my command, in cooking
#Text= soldiers  '   rations, and that it appears perfectly to answer all
#Text= purposes.
#Text=It possesses many advantages--viz., the small quantity of
#Text= fuel required, its lightness and portability, and requiring, when
#Text= in use, the attendance of only one man.
#Text=It is in every respect
#Text= preferable to the cooking coppers generally used in barracks.
#Text=R.
#Text=W.
#Text=HUEY, Lieut.
#Text=-Col.,
#Text= _Commanding 2nd Bat. 1st Royal Regiment_.
#Text=CAMP, KAMARA, _1st June, 1856_.
#Text=I have much pleasure in bearing my testimony to the great advantage
#Text=
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= CAMP BEFORE SEBASTOPOL, FOURTH DIVISION,
#Text= _June 14th, 1856_.
#Text=Major-General Garrett approves highly of the cooking-stoves
#Text= introduced by Monsieur Soyer, which have been made trial of by all
#Text= the regiments of the Fourth Division, and have given great
#Text= satisfaction to the men, and have been approved by commanding
#Text= officers.
#Text=In a standing camp, or in quarters, they are admirable; they can be
#Text= put up in an instant anywhere, either in or out of doors, and they
#Text= never smoke.
#Text=If attention is paid to the proportions of meat,
#Text= water, and the necessary ingredients, when cooking commences, the
#Text= most careless soldier can scarcely fail in making a good mess.
#Text=There is also a great saving of fuel; and as only a certain amount
#Text= of fire can be kept going, a steady and even process of cooking is
#Text= insured, by which, without any great skill on the part of the
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= MALTA, _September 8th, 1856_.
#Text=SIR,--In reply to your letter requesting me to give you my opinion
#Text= on the subject of your military cooking stove, I now beg to give
#Text= you the opinion I have formed of them.
#Text=I will first mention that the stove was used by each of the
#Text= companies of the 47th Regiment in succession.
#Text=The non-commissioned
#Text= officers and soldiers all spoke most favourably of it.
#Text=The portable cooking stove has, in my mind, many important
#Text= advantages to recommend it--one very important one being that it
#Text= can cook in any situation whatsoever, and in any weather, and with
#Text= the smallest possible consumption of fuel of any kind which may be
#Text= available--a very great consideration in localities where fuel is
#Text= scarce or difficult of access.
#Text=I imagine those stoves would have
#Text= answered admirably for cooking in the trenches before Sebastopol,
#Text= taking little room, consuming little fuel, and showing but little
#Text=smoke, and cooking the food as securely and perfectly in bad
#Text= weather as in fine.
#Text=For field hospitals they would answer admirably, _especially as
#Text= carrying their own fuel_ on a march.
#Text=The cooking for the sick could
#Text= commence instantly on the halt taking place.
#Text=I think here at Malta they would be very useful in many of the
#Text= encampments; in fact, anywhere that troops are suddenly placed they
#Text= (the cooking stoves) would be found of great use.
#Text=Even they could
#Text= answer very well in the event of troops having on any emergency to
#Text= embark in vessels inadequately provided with cooking apparatus.
#Text=Fully convinced of their merits, I wish the invention all the
#Text= military success and encouragement it deserves.
#Text=I have the honour to be your very obedient servant,
#Text=
#Text= M.
#Text=J.
#Text=HALEY,
#Text= _Colonel commanding 47th Regiment_.
#Text=To Monsieur Alexis Soyer.
#Text=P.S.
#Text=There is one observation I cannot help adding, which is that,
#Text= however desirable it is to give the army improved utensils for
#Text= cooking, little progress will be made in military cookery and
#Text= teaching the soldiers to turn such rations or other articles of
#Text= food to account in the most advantageous and ready manner, unless
#Text= it is some one person  '  s particular business to teach cooking.
#Text=We
#Text= ought to have a non-commissioned officer for the special duty, and
#Text= who would be responsible for imparting instruction in that most
#Text= essential craft; recollecting a most important _maxime de
#Text= guerre_:--"C  '  est la soupe qui fait le soldat."
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 13, KENSINGTON PARK TERRACE NORTH, _July, 1857_.
#Text=DEAR SIR,--I understand that you are about to publish some
#Text= observations respecting your valuable labours in the culinary
#Text= department in the military hospitals of Scutari and the Crimea.
#Text=If
#Text=you permit me, I shall be happy to add a few remarks, such as
#Text= occurred to me during the period I was engaged by the Government as
#Text= one of the physicians in the Barrack Hospital.
#Text=One of the first
#Text= duties in the treatment of the sick was to ascertain the quality of
#Text= the food adapted to invalids labouring under every form of fever,
#Text= of acute and chronic diarrhoea, and especially dysentery.
#Text=It is
#Text= in vain to attempt to cure these diseases by medicines only; a
#Text= carefully regulated diet was of the first consequence; and I was
#Text= early disappointed and embarrassed by the wretched state of the
#Text= kitchens and diet intended for the sick.
#Text=I was in the habit of
#Text= frequenting the kitchen which belonged to the division of the
#Text= hospital in which I was doing duty, and observing the mode of
#Text= cooking, and soon found that the soldier-cooks were quite ignorant
#Text= of their art.
#Text=I have constantly examined and tasted the mutton and
#Text= fowls, the soups, the vegetables, and the puddings, and I do not
#Text= hesitate to affirm that they were as unpalatable and unsavoury and
#Text= as objectionable as they could be.
#Text=The practice of cooking the
#Text= fowls was to put them into nets--a dozen or more in one net;
#Text= several nets were placed in large coppers; and then to boil them as
#Text= rapidly as possible, with fierce heat.
